ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of <u>intellectual challenge</u> of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the <u>workload</u> of this course was:
Which of the following best describes your mode of learning in this course?
options: virtual seminar or other discussion format
in-person seminar or other discussion format

narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I feel like I have better bearings of cuban history and culture.

In this course, I was exposed to a strong overview of Cuban history, and learned about this history through a unique mix of sources. I greatly appreciated the opportunity to delve into a country that I knew relatively little about without being constrained by dominant textbooks.

I gained a broad overview of Cuba's history and culture from the 1600s up until the 21st century. We discussed slave revolts, Cuba's tricky relationship with the US, Cuban literature & music, Cuban fashion during the 1980s, the exile community, and of course the Cuban Revolution.

History and culture of Cuba from the pre-revolutionary period to the modern day, with a big focus on Cuba's struggle for independence and Revolutionary Cuba. Class had a strong mixture of historical readings that offered background and selections of cultural sources -- literature, film, music, etc. I definitely came out of this class with an understanding of the nuances of post-Revolutionary Cuba, its contradictions and achievements.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: While I think the readings for the course were interesting, there were no trigger warnings for pieces that were quite graphic and traumatic. Furthermore, our discussions in class primarily centered around mainstream notions of Cuban history and left out the perspectives of most communities except for in specific moments. I think the class could be improved by a syllabus and focus that includes a better variety of perspectives beyond just hinting that they exist or are hard to find in "academic sources."

The texts used in this course are its strongest element! They are varied, interesting, and engaging, and help to paint a fairly complete picture (especially for a survey course). I think that this course's discussion elements could have been slightly strengthenedthe professor often had a lot of material prepared, so the seminar occasionally felt more like a lecture, and I think that a more student-led discussion could have been fruitful. However, I acknowledge that the online seminar format has been less-than-ideal, which was a certainly a factor of my class experience.

It is one of the best classes I have taken at Yale. Professor Laguna has done an amazing job fine tuning the course. Each reading and assignment had a specific purpose that made the experience as enjoyable as possible.

Strengths are that Dr. Laguna is really really great and I learned a ton about Cuba in a pretty accessible but also rigorous way. Weaknesses were that we did not get to go to Cuba, of course, and that Dr. Funes no longer is co-teaching.

Strengths: GREAT professor!! The assigned readings and discussions were very engaging. The workload was manageable (especially since the readings were interesting). Content was very strong. 

Weaknesses: I can't think of any!

Strengths: Prof. Laguna is a engaging; course material is well-selected; Cuba is fascinating to learn about in-depth
weaknesses: not many. class is really well organized.

narratives.question_text: Among the practices in this course geared toward learning during the COVID-19 pandemic, which succeeded and which could be improved? Please comment on course practices that allowed for virtual engagement. (Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I thought our discussions over zoom went as well as they could have. I would have enjoyed more breakout rooms throughout the class periods and other interactive activities beyond just discussions.

The professor was extremely accessible and flexible in light of the COVID-19 pandemiche was welcoming in virtual office hours and class, and supportive of students' needs. I did feel that the course struggled somewhat as a virtual seminar, which was generally a theme across my online learning experience.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I would recommend this class solely because there are no other classes that teach so thoroughly about Cuba. Yet, the course itself could benefit from some updates/inclusion of more perspectives other than the white cis-male perspective.
Yes! This course is a really excellent overview of Cuban history, and I learned a lot. This semester, we didn't even get to go to Cuba, but it was still 100% worth it.
Yes
Yes!! If  you  have an interest  in Cuba, this is an excellent survey  of Cuban cultural (and political) history

Yes! I learned so much from this class! What I loved about this course is that it situates Cuban culture within a historical context; we would read about a certain historical period and then have other readings about a specific aspect of that period (e.g. fashion, music, literature). Even though it was over zoom, the discussions were very interesting and engaging. The professor is also very kind and understanding! Highly recommend this class regardless of your major!
Definitely, if you can get in take it. Prof. Laguna is great. Understanding Cuba in a nuanced manner instead of from one side of political rhetoric is valuable as heck.
